abstracts.cdata!:
Overall, the outcome of the project is
            rated as satisfactory: the project achieved most of its
            objectives and generally provided a model for improving
            primary health care delivery in urban and peri-urban areas.
            Some of the key lessons learned are: 1) It is vital to
            involve all players who participate in developing the sector
            in project preparation and supervision; and to decentralize
            decisionmaking and financial resource allocation. 2) Project
            objectives and design should be clear to all those involved
            in project execution; and implementation procedures must be
            sufficiently flexible to adapt to rapid changes in
            government policies and structure. (The flexibility of
            project design and credit agreements allowed quick,
            extensive changes to be made, which drastically improved
            project performance). 3) Creating an organizational culture
            based on participation, open dialogue, team work, client
            orientation, and the use of total quality management
            techniques leads to increased productivity. 4) Strong
            commitment among high government levels has to exist in
            order for there to be enforceable sub-contracts between
            government agencies. 5) If the administrative and financial
            department has weaknesses, it is useful to enlist an
            internal auditor with experience in Bank procurement
            procedures. 6) It is crucial to ensure that the terms of
            reference are well-written, that only qualified consultants
            are hired, that construction guides and procedural manuals
            are developed and applied.

18152154.theme: Population and reproductive health,Health system performance,Other communicable diseases,Child health,Administrative and civil service reform
18152154.trustfund:
UN007910-WATER SUPP. FOR LOW-INCOME COMMUNITIES,TF031471-BOLIVIA - HEALTH,TF025268-PHRD-SECOND INTEGRATED HEALTH
            DEVELOPMENT PROJECT,TF024849-HUMAN RESOURCES UNIT IN LA PAZ,UN007065-UNDP-WB WATER & SANITATION PROGRAM,TF024852-SOCIAL SECTORS UNIT IN LA PAZ

abstracts.cdata!:
The project objective is to improve
            maternal and child health care. The project would: (a)
            support the extension of basic health services; (b) improve
            the effectiveness of basic health services; and (c)
            strengthen central policy making and coordination of
            investment in health. Specifically, the project would
            include three components. First, a service delivery
            component consists of extending maternal and child care in
            the marginal and low-income areas of La Paz, El Alto,
            Cochabamba and Santa Cruz. The credit would finance the
            extension of pre- and post-natal care, reproductive health
            care, child development and nutritional control, prevention
            and control of diarrheal and respiratory diseases. The
            credit would also finance construction, rehabilitation,
            equipment and management of health centers. The second
            component is human resources development consisting of the
            development of decentralized training capacity, training and
            supervision of selected staff, and health education
            campaigns. The third component is institutional development
            covering the reorganization of the Ministry of Social
            Welfare and Public Health (MPSSP), in its Planning, Human
            Resources, Administration and General directorates, and in
            the regional units involved in the project.
